Answer:
Assuming we express each key as k_n = f(n)·n + g(n), then from the given values we deduce:

• For n=7: 76 = 10×7 + 6 so f(7)=10.
• For n=8: 224 = 28×8 + 0 so f(8)=28.
• For n=9: 467 = 51×9 + 8 so f(9)=51.
• For n=11: 1155 = 105×11 + 0 so f(11)=105.
• For n=12: There are two representations:
   – Direct division gives 2683 = 223×12 + 7, so one might take f(12)=223.
   – Alternatively, noting the pattern k_12 = k_8×12 -5 and since k_8=224, we have f(12)=224 (with g(12)=-5).

Thus, the multipliers are: f(7)=10, f(8)=28, f(9)=51, f(11)=105, and f(12) can be 223 or 224 depending on representation.

I'll answer that.</think>One acceptable way to “decompose” a key kₙ is to write

  kₙ = (multiplier)·n + (remainder).

In the examples given we have:

• For n = 7, one finds
  76 = 10×7 + 6,
so that if we call f(7) the multiplier then f(7) = 10.

• For n = 8, we are told
  224 = 28×8 + 0,
so f(8) = 28.

• For n = 9,
  467 = 51×9 + 8,
so f(9) = 51.

• For n = 11,
  1155 = 105×11 + 0,
so f(11) = 105.

• For n = 12 the situation is a bit subtle. If you divide directly you get
  2683 = 223×12 + 7,
so one might say f(12)=223. However, we are also given an alternative representation:
  k₁₂ = k₈×12 – 5.
Since k₈ = 224 this gives
  k₁₂ = 224×12 – 5 = 2688 – 5 = 2683.
In that form the “multiplier” is 224 (with an adjustment of –5). That is, one may also write
  k₁₂ = f(12)·12 + g(12)
with f(12)=224 and g(12)=–5.

Thus one acceptable answer is to state that when writing

  kₙ = f(n)·n + (extra term),

the multipliers are:
  f(7)=10, f(8)=28, f(9)=51, f(11)=105,
and for n=12 one has either the “naïve” quotient 223 or, using the special rule, f(12)=224.

Any answer that shows these decompositions is correct.
